subject: Re: Which parameter in my list failed?
msgSnippet: ... Hm, good point. My use in this particular case was a search in which any of 6 optional parameters may be sent in, so I thought to use parameterized to test
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "David Saff" <saff@...> wrote:
> Parameterized is designed to work with datasets that are expensive to
> navigate, like filesystem folders or database tables or huge XML
> files. A JUnit design rule is that all the tests have to be named
> before any of them is run, and naming should not be an expensive
> activity.

Hm, good point. My use in this particular case was a search in which
any of 6 optional parameters may be sent in, so I thought to use
parameterized to test the various combinations of empty and non-empty
search parameters (i.e. "sent name only", "sent city and state only"
etc.).

I even made factories to represent the expected values from the
database and set that as the last ("expected") value for each parameter.

So it was a small set computationally but large enough that I thought
it would increase readability and usability using parameterized.

Perhaps there was a better way to do it.

Gabriel.
